Description: Egyptian sealing in fired clay. A sealing impressed by two intaglio gems, one with a human head, probably male, to right, the other with a facing bust of Osiris with an atef crown and a broad collar. The back has an impression of the papyrus document to which it was attached, with a hole for the string that bound the package. Red-brown Nile silt with white inclusions and mica.
Curator's comments: Found with BM1886,0401.1701 and 1700. Petrie dates this group as 2nd century AD (Petrie 1886, 100, pl.XX, nos 20-22). Clay resembles local Naukratis red Nile silt fabric, but could have been sent here from another location on the Nile Delta. '1' in pencil.

Another seal impression found during the excavation of J. Lauffray in a Ptolemaic settlement at Karnak presents a very similar motif, animal wearing an Atef crown. Lauffray, J. 1995. La chapelle d'Achôris à Karnak. I, Les fouilles, l'architecture, le mobilier et l'anastylose, Paris.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (E95)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 100, pl. XX, no. 22)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (PB.07)
Condition: Clay is very fragile and cracked.
